tacTile.net
Class TouchAPI

java.lang.Object
  tacTile.net.TouchAPI

public class TouchAPI
extends java.lang.Object

TouchAPI is an addition to the Processing Libraries written so Processing applications could communicate with the TacTile.
Tac Tile is a Multi-touch table begin researched at the Electronic Visualization Lab at the University of Illinois at Chicago.

The TouchAPI constructor creates and manages communications between a Touch Server and a Processing application.

CONNECTION : Touch Servers

    Connections are facilitated by simply calling the TouchApi constructors. However, there are two constructors that can be called depending on the type of touch server.
    • TacTile Touch Server: Processing applications that are loaded onto TacTile for testing can access touch data from the TacTile touch server. This is done by simply calling this constructor:
      TouchAPI(Object owner)

    • Local Touch Server: Often times during development a Multi-Touch Pad is used. Construction and drivers for such a device can be found here. Installing the drivers allows input on the Multi-Touch Pad to be sent to your personal computer. Your machine is now a local touch server! In conjunction with TouchAPI, both the local touch server and Processing application can run on the same machine. This is done by simply calling this constructor:
      TouchAPI(Object owner, int data_port)

    • Specified Touch Server: This is an alternative constructor that will allow the user to specify all the information needed to make a connection with TouchAPI:
      TouchAPI(Object owner, int data_port, int msg_port, String serverIP)

    After a connection is formed by either one of these constructors, TouachAPI is called to collect touch data from the Touch Server.
RETRIEVAL : Touch Data
    The data is then processed and stored within two ArrayLists inside the TouchAPI:
    • dataTouchList:
        For more advanced users who want to manage their own touch data. This arrayList of Touches is the parsed data that is sent back from the touch server.

        The dataTouchList has an initial maximum size of 200. Any touches beyond the maximum will still be added to the list. However, the oldest touch in the list will be deleted. Essentially only 200 of the most recent touches will be kept in the list. This list size can be retrieved and altered via: getTouchData(int ) , getLeastRecentTouchData(), & getMostRecentTouchData().

        The data within the dataTouchList can be accessed by the following methods:
          Retrieve data :
          getTouchData(int ) , getLeastRecentTouchData() & getMostRecentTouchData().

          Clearing the list :
          clearAllButEarliestTouchData() & clearAllDataTouches().

          List Attributes :
          dataListIsEmpty() & dataListSize().

    • managedTouchList:
        This list manages the touch data for you. The data for each touch is stored within an instance of Touches. A new touch's finger ID is first compared with all the existing touches in the managedTouchList. If the finger ID is not present the touch is assumed to be new and added to the managedTouchList. If it is present, then the x Position, y Position, time stamp and intensity are updated.

        Once the finger ID is checked, the managedTouchList is then refreshed. Each touch has a life span in milliseconds. During the refresh period, if a touch exceeds its life time it is removed from the list. The default value for a life time is 80 milliseconds. This can be changed via the function: setTouchLifeTime(long time). The entire managedTouchList and info about the list can be accessed by the following methods:
          Retrieve list :
          getManagedList()

    • TouchListener:
        TouchListener is an interface that the user can implement in order to receive touch events as they occur. The user must create a class that implements the TouchListener class. Once this is done an instance of that class must be passed to the TouchAPI via the setTouchListener() method.

Version:
0.2
Author:
Dennis Chau - Koracas@gmail.com
, Arthur Nishimoto - anishimoto42@gmail.com

Constructor Detail

TouchAPI

public TouchAPI(java.lang.Object owner)
Default constructor that will create a connection between the TacTile touch server and a Processing Application.

Parameters:
owner - the parent object so the class knows how to get back to the Processing Application

TouchAPI

public TouchAPI(java.lang.Object owner,
                int data_port)
Constructor that will create a connection between a local touch server and a Processing Application. Ideally this would be used along with the OmegaTracker Server running on the same machine as the Processing Application. In order to establish this connection, all that is needed is a port where the data should be stored. The constructor will automatically connect to the machine that the TouchAPI is instantiated on.

Parameters:
owner - the parent object so the class knows how to get back to the Processing Application
data_port - the port where the touch server should send the data. A suggested port number is 7000.

TouchAPI

public TouchAPI(java.lang.Object owner,
                int clientPort,
                int serverPort,
                java.lang.String serverIP)
Constructor that creates a new connection between a touch server and a Processing application. In order to form a connection the following information is needed:
  • data_port : the port on the Touch Client where the data should be sent
  • msg_port : the port on the Touch Server where the message to begin data transfer is sent
  • serverIP : the IP address of the Touch Server.
If this information is correct, this constructor can be used to form a connection between the Touch Server and the Processing Application. TouchAPI will send a "being data transfer" message to the specified port and server. Once this message is sent, it listens to the data_port for any incoming data. Note: If the Touch Server is running on the same computer as the Touch Client, the serverIP should be set to the IP of the localhost.

Parameters:
owner - the parent object so the class knows how to get back to the Processing Application
clientPort - the port the Touch Client listens on for touch messages from the Touch Server.
serverPort - the IP address of the Touch Server.
serverIP - the port the Touch Server listens on for new clients.
Method Detail

dispose

public void dispose()
Close the connections that are made to touch server and the Processing Application. This method is automatically called by Processing when the PApplet shuts down.
You DO NOT need to call this method.

getTouchData

public Touches getTouchData(int index)
Returns a specified Touches in the dataTouchList. If the list is empty, a Null is returned.
Once the touch is retrieved, the Touches are removed .

Parameters:
index - The index of the desired touch
Returns:
Touches if dataTouchList is not empty
OR
Null if dataTouchList is empty

getLeastRecentTouchData

public Touches getLeastRecentTouchData()
Returns a the oldest touch on the dataTouchList. If the list is empty, a Null is returned.
Once the touch is retrieved, the Touches are removed .

Returns:
Touches if dataTouchList is not empty -OR- Null if dataTouchList is empty

getMostRecentTouchData

public Touches getMostRecentTouchData()
Returns a the newest touch on the dataTouchList. If the list is empty, a Null is returned.
Once the touch is retrieved, the Touches are removed .

Returns:
Touches if dataTouchList is not empty -OR- Null if dataTouchList is empty

clearAllDataTouches

public void clearAllButEarliestTouchData()

getManagedList

public java.util.ArrayList<Touches> getManagedList()
Returns a copy of the new managed list which gives more accurate touchID tracking at the cost of sensitivity/number of touches and also calls process() so you don't have to call it separately if you are using getTouch(up/down/drag) for gestures .

Returns:
ArrayList

getNewTouches

public java.util.ArrayList<Touches> getNewTouches()
Returns a list of new touches. Same as getTouchesDown(). process() or getManagedList() should be called before this.

Returns:
ArrayList

getExpiredTouches

public java.util.ArrayList<Touches> getExpiredTouches()
Returns a list of recently expired touches. Same as getTouchesUp(). process() or getManagedList() should be called before this.

Returns:
ArrayList

ArrayList

Returns a list of recent touch ups. Same as getExpiredTouches(). process() or getManagedList() should be called before this.

Returns:
ArrayList

getTouchesDown

public java.util.ArrayList<Touches> getTouchesDown()
Returns a list of recent touch downs. Same as getNewTouches(). process() or getManagedList() should be called before this.

Returns:
ArrayList

getOldManagedList

public java.util.ArrayList<Touches> getOldManagedList()
Returns a copy of the old managedTouchList which does not track touchIDs as well, but gives more touches for better sensitivity. This does not call process() for getTouch(up/down/move).

Returns:
ArrayList

getGestureList

public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> getGestureList()

Returns:
int

managedListIsEmpty

public boolean managedListIsEmpty()
Returns true if managedTouchList is empty

Returns:
boolean

process

public void process()
Required to be called before any calls related to the touch downs, ups, or moves. Also used for more accurate tracking of fingerIDs at the cost of maximum number of possible touches. Should not be called with getManagedList() since it already calls process().

setTouchLifeTime

public void setTouchLifeTime(long time)
Set the lifetime of a touch within the managedTouchList

Parameters:
time - the lifetime of a touch in milliseconds. Default value is 80.

setResidueLifeTime

public void setResidueLifeTime(float time)
Set the residue lifetime of a touch.

Parameters:
time - the lifetime of a touch in milliseconds. Default value is 150.

setResidueRadius

public void setResidueRadius(float r)
Sets the radius where nearby touches will be considered the same touch.

Parameters:
r - radius in pixels.

log_on

Function for log messages

Parameters:
out - the log string

__tacTile_Polling__

public void __tacTile_Polling__(byte[] data,
                                java.lang.String ip,
                                int port)
In order to perform parsing of the incoming touch data, this method is needed.
You DO NOT need to implement/use this method.

Parameters:
data - the data that is transmitted
IP - the IP of the data's origin
port - the port the data was sent from
See Also:
processData(byte[] data)

__tacTile_TimeOut__

public void __tacTile_TimeOut__()
In order to perform proper handling when TacTile is idle, this method is needed.
You DO NOT need to implement/use this method.

Parameters:
data - the data that is transmitted
IP - the IP of the data's origin
port - the port the data was sent from
See Also:
processData(byte[] data)
